body: Hi @etc-crontab  what Apache JIRA ticket this PR belongs to?

Hi @smiklosovic, thanks for your reply.
Well, based on https://cassandra.apache.org/_/development/documentation.html, section "GitHub based work flow", I thought this kind of fix could be done without a Jira ticket. My bad.
I created one here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-17508.

> @thingtwin1 thanks for pulling those changes. I think it might be more practical to rebase on top of trunk with `git rebase trunk` instead of merging from trunk on top of the patch branch. That way the PR would show the proposed changes on top of trunk's commits, without the additional merge commit.
> 
> It seems that the removal of the property breaks the dtests [`GuardrailCollectionSizeOnSSTableWriteTest`](https://github.com/apache/cassandra/blob/935bcf1e8732a4138c15205896945c2f02ddb844/test/distributed/org/apache/cassandra/distributed/test/guardrails/GuardrailCollectionSizeOnSSTableWriteTest.java#L57) and [`GuardrailItemsPerCollectionOnSSTableWriteTest`](https://github.com/apache/cassandra/blob/935bcf1e8732a4138c15205896945c2f02ddb844/test/distributed/org/apache/cassandra/distributed/test/guardrails/GuardrailItemsPerCollectionOnSSTableWriteTest.java#L52). Those tests are still mentioning the removed property.

rebased and fixed the failing tests
we need a jira ticket in jira.apache.org for this ever be considered to be merged.
Note, test_cqlsh_completion.py and test_cqlsh_output.py do properly call remove_db in tearDownClass.  This test is simply missing it.
Modulo rolling that one errant change I suggested back, LGTM +1
Perfect. I think I broke Jira with all my worklog updates - at least, I cannot load the page successfully now - so I'll just leave my +1 here.
Reviewed, starting merge. Thanks for the review.
Reviewed, starting merge. Thanks for the review.
Ok @jonmeredith, your feedback on the unit tests inspired me to make them... not paltry. Sorry for the churn; I'm much happier with where this ended up.

I think I went through all comments, with the exception of a couple of items (on `dumpMemtables` and index building) for which I need to review the persistent memory memtable code. Starting that review now.

with latest changes track warnings no longer exist

```
$ egrep -r 'track_warning|track-warning|trackwarning' src/ test/
$
```
@smiklosovic I didn't see this merged, was it closed by mistake?

I have rebased the PR, CI is running:
* [j8](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/adelapena/cassandra/1487/workflows/9fbcfe8a-97b3-4af1-b161-c1b65e5d2a16)
* [j11](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/adelapena/cassandra/1487/workflows/bad9f922-c222-4ef2-b0de-d3b7d285999d)
Guessing we'll also want a Jenkins run once any obvious issues surfaced by CircleCI have been fixed?
I have not closed this. I wonder who did that. (or at least I dont remeber it?). Probably mistake, yes.
@bschoening I do not have access to that branch anymore. Seems like "mysto" account do not exist anymore?
Talking to @ekaterinadimitrova2 to lower the risk of breaking `generate.sh` I reverted that logic and used the new scripts to generate the diff

I opened a new PR in https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/1587, maybe we can close this one and resume there?
Review feedback can be fixed there.
@javeme thanks for submitting the PR! Would you [please log a JIRA ticket](https://k8ssandra.atlassian.net/jira/secure/CreateIssue.jspa?pid=10004) for this so we have background info? Cheers! 🍻

@ErickRamirezAU Thanks.
I have created a JIRA issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/CASSANDRA/issues/CASSANDRA-17581

> @adelapena I don't know about getting rid of them, would need to see original JIRA more closely to see the full intent. I would be concerned getting rid of a new feature when we can port it to the new configs without much prob

I don't see a particular reason in the original ticket for having the nodetool commands beyond the need to be able to dynamically udpdate the properties. Raw JMX already does that, although the nodetool command make it more handy. I don't have a problem keeping those trivial commands, beyond the lack of homogeneity with the other guardrails, which doesn't seem a big problem, even it they become redundant when we add the ability to manipulate guardrails through virtual tables.

I believe I finally found a solution for the upgrade problem. It's has the same cause as CASSANDRA-12236,
CASSANDRA-12697 and CASSANDRA-13382: the new column is not accepted by older nodes and must be hidden from the propagated schema when not set.

The solution I went with is to remove the `memtable` value from the schema table when it is at default, i.e. replace `"default"` with `null` for that case, make sure the column definition for the sent mutation only lists columns that are actually present in the mutation, and use a row deletion to ensure an older `memtable` value does not persist when switching from a schema that contains it, i.e. when resetting a table's memtable implementation to default.

Please take a look at these changes -- the tests appear to be passing, but I'd like to know your opinion on this approach, especially the schema row deletion.

The approach sounds good to me, and indeed it fixes the upgrade tests: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/adelapena/cassandra/1511/workflows/897b84ae-2d90-4ef2-9adc-c17cef0c78cf

I understand it won't work if a table was created/altered with a non-default memtable by an upgraded node in a mixed version cluster, do we need to support that case?

> I understand it won't work if a table was created/altered with a non-default memtable by an upgraded node in a mixed version cluster, do we need to support that case?

The situation is the same as the CDC flag: it's not useable unless the whole cluster is upgraded to 4.1. I think we can live with that; as I understand it we don't have a way to distribute version-specific schema changes to the cluster, and stripped flags from the schema sent to a lower-version node might end up being propagated (although not including a deletion and thus not overriding the value on any node that did get the original change, but what about any newly-joining ones?).
Do we want to publicize the API in `NEWS.txt`, or should we delay that until we have alternative bundled implementations?

> The situation is the same as the CDC flag: it's not useable unless the whole cluster is upgraded to 4.1. I think we can live with that

Makes sense.
> Do we want to publicize the API in `NEWS.txt`, or should we delay that until we have alternative bundled implementations?

I'd say we want. Although we don't have multiple implementations the feature allows anyone out there to provide their own impls, so it might still be useful and thus worthy of mention.
+1 at least mentioning this new capability in NEWS.txt

Could we get more detail on the help output for these scripts? It's not clear what they're supposed to do, how they work, how to test, etc w/out opening them up. Nothing in readme.md and the help output is:
```./circle-ci-config.py
usage: circle-ci-config.py [-h] [--stdout] target
circle-ci-config.py: error: the following arguments are required: target
```

Also, having "HIGHER" as a target when we have LOWRES, MIDRES, HIGHRES seems pretty confusing for me:
```
51 targets = {
52         'MIDRES': {
...
89         'HIGHER': {
```

I went through the unit test failures for `ShardedSkipListMemtable`. They fall in several categories:
- Complaints about `NativePoolCleaner` being spawned. This is a side effect of instantiating a different memtable; the default has a special treatment to ensure that the allocator is not initialized with it.
- Problems with `ByteOrderedPartitioner` and `OrderPreservingPartitioner`. These cannot be used in combination with sharding.
- `CreateTest` and `AlterTest` failing by expecting the default to be `SkipListMemtable`.
- `MemtableSizeTest` needs to be fixed for the sharded memtable (this is also run with the normal memtable default).

I will consider these tests successful and switch back to the normal default.
Rebased from trunk + formatting in a separate commit
Tested this patch using CCM and verified that certificate in outbound_keystore is being received by the server during mTLS internode connection.

@jonmeredith There are tests in `SSLFactoryTest.testServerSocketShouldUseKeystore`  `SSLFactoryTest.testClientSocketShouldUseOutboundKeystore` which check if right keystore is used for a given type of connection for creating SSLContext. However I don't have a way of checking the file from which SSLContext is created from and SSLContext object.

spoke with @jonmeredith in slack, I will revert back to `upgradeFrom(v30)`.  He pointed out that we really want to test all upgrade paths, but don't have a clear solution on how to do that given CI and JVM Metaspace limitations (testing out POC but likely to punt if not working by EOD)

I gave up on trying to make the tests better... we really need a template system or code generation system where we create 1 class for each path...  given how we currently do this we need `*Test.java` files for each, so something would need to know how and generate it!  We could do this via a script, but then we need this to work on all environments... we could do this with an annotation processor, but need to make things more complex at build time since annotation processors need to be compiled before the tests compile

looking into `org.apache.cassandra.distributed.upgrade.CompactStorageUpgradeTest#compactStoragePagingTest`, not sure why it OOMs when it matches the same pattern as other tests...

If you disable the queries (that do paging) then it passes... so something must leak there?
just switched to `.singleUpgrade` for CompactStorageUpgradeTest; I think a leak is happening but don't have the bandwidth to look into that...
@jeffwidman - good suggestion.  When this is ready to merge, I can update the patch.

> Looks good to me, +1. I have left a few formatting nits on [this commit](https://github.com/adelapena/cassandra/commit/f5ff92ed108c72dc39b373ae87a2ce1104a14842), they can be incorporated during commit if you agree.

yes the formatting comments look good to me!

CI [j8](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/bereng/cassandra/687/workflows/43b84bed-05ab-4343-b043-667f5d7bfde6)

Failures aligned to current jenkins trunk
